thread.title: Obviously not-from-Boston Bill Murray says Red Sox fans are ‘unbearable’ - Celebrity news
thread.title_full: Obviously not-from-Boston Bill Murray says Red Sox fans are ‘unbearable’ - Celebrity news

author: boston.com
title: Obviously not-from-Boston Bill Murray says Red Sox fans are ‘unbearable’ - Celebrity news
text:
To kick off his week of shows in Brooklyn, Jimmy Kimmel invited Bill Murray to emerge from his “Cubs-induced depression” Monday for a nice little visit to Jimmy Kimmel Live!
Though Murray came dressed for the LOLs in a costume and stage makeup, when Kimmel asked the Chicago-born actor about the Red Sox, he was suddenly all business. He shared his real feelings about Boston fans.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below “Do you feel like [Cubs fans] will lose something when [the Cubs win the World Series]?” Kimmel asked. “The Red Sox used to be special, and now they’re just another good team.”
“I agree. Now, let’s talk about the Red Sox for a second, OK?” Murray said. He continued:
The Boston Red Sox used to be the most gracious losers. I was always impressed by how gracious they were in defeat. They really applauded the other team and how well they played. And then they won a couple World Series, and now they’re unbearable. They’re just unbearable fans. Something really changed with them. I don’t know, they’re just a little different. And it’s sort of natural. It’s like being famous. I hope the Cubs fans don’t do that.
This is the second time this year Murray has hated on the Sox: in April, he referred to them as “ terrible winners .”
Guess we have to root for the Mets now .
Boston-area comedians:
 Canton-born comic Bill Burr owns the record for most consecutive sold-out shows at the Wilbur Theatre. James Kronzer/Netflix Louis C.K., who grew up in Newton, got his start at open mic nights in Boston during the 1980s comedy boom. Monica Schipper/Getty Images for New York Comedy Festival Born in Concord, ‘The Office’ star Steve Carrell grew up in Acton before joining the famed Second City troupe in Chicago. His wife Nancy grew up in Cohasset, and got her start as a member of a Boston College improv group. Michael Nelson/EPA UMass-Boston alum and Cambridge native Lenny Clarke is still a force to be reckoned with on the city’s comedy scene. Yoon S. Byun/Globe Staff Cambridge-born comic Dane Cook kicked off his comedy career right here in Boston. Yoon S. Byun/Globe Staff ’Hot Tub Time Machine’ star and UMass-Anherst alum Rob Corddry originally hails from Weymouth. Richard Shotwell/Invision/Associated Press Boston comics owe a debt to Barry Crimmins, who founded two of the area’s most popular comedy clubs in the 1980’s - The Ding Ho and Stiches. Heather Ainsworth/Associated Press for The Boston Globe ‘Catastrophe’ star Rob Delaney was born in Boston. Danvers’ Nick DiPaolo is a frequent collaborator with fellow Boston comic Louis C.K. Ethan Miller/Getty Images ‘SNL’ alum Rachel Dratch grew up in Lexington. Evan Agostini/Associated Press Billed as ‘The Godfather of Boston Comedy,’ Don Gavin has been making Bostonians laugh for decades. ’Last Comic Standing’ alum Gary Gulman was born in Boston. Matthew J. Lee/Globe Staff ‘Daily Show’ star John Hodgman is a native of Brookline. Stephen Lovekin/Getty Images for Comedy Central Lexington’s Pete Holmes kicked off his comedy career as a member of an improv troupe at Gordon College. Stephen Lovekin ‘The Mindy Project’ and ‘The Office’ star Mindy Kaling grew up in Cambridge and was a member of The Dog Day Players comedy troupe at Dartmouth College. Loic Venance/AFP/Getty Images Boston-born comic Robert Kelly plays Louis C.K.’s brother on the FX series ‘Louie.’ Stephen Lovekin/Getty Images Needham native Jen Kirkman majored in acting at Emerson College before pursuing a career in comedy. One of the city’s most famous comedians, Denis Leary taught comedy classes in Boston before his career took off. Matthew J. Lee/Globe Staff Former ‘Tonight Show’ host and Andover native Jay Leno kicked off his comedy career while studying at Emerson College in the 1970’s. Adam Hunger/Reuters Kevin Meaney cut his teeth in Boston during the early days of the city’s comedy scene. Paul Drinkwater/NBC Eugene Mirman, who grew up in Lexington, holds a comedy festival in Boston every year. Julia Cumes for the Boston Globe ’The Office’ actor B.J. Novak grew up in Newton and was a member of the ‘Harvard Lampoon’ and Hasty Pudding Club at Harvard University. Amy Sussman/Invision/Associated Press Brookline native Conan O'Brien served as president for both ‘The Harvard Crimson’ and the ‘Harvard Lampoon’ during his time at Harvard. Mario Anzuoni/Reuters Former Roxbury resident Patrice O'Neal was a star football player at West Roxbury High School before making the leap into comedy. O’Neal passed away in 2011. Wendy Maeda/Globe Staff Boston-born comedian John Pinette passed away in 2014. Lucas Jackson/Reuters ’SNL’ and ‘Parks and Recreation’ star Amy Poehler was born in Newton. Kevork Djansezian/Reuters Paula Poundstone, who grew up in Sudbury, got her start during open mic nights in Boston during the 1970s. Carin Baer/Bravo Prolific podcaster and UFC commentator Joe Rogan grew up in Newton. Mitchell Zachs/South Beach Comedy Festival/Associated Press Actor and comedian Jenny Slate was born in Milton. Richard Shotwell/Invision/Associated Press Charlestown’s Steve Sweeney has been a staple of the Boston comedian scene since the early 1970’s. George Rizer/Globe Staff Comedian and actor Jimmy Tingle hails from Cambridge. Ellen Shub The father of Boston comedy, Cambridge’s Steven Wright, put the city’s scene on the map during his first appearance on ‘The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson.’ Jorge Rios
